file_metadata.title: Control flow in active inference systems Part II: Tensor networks as general models of control flow

chunks.text: Living systems must efficiently manage resources in complex environments, requiring a control system to activate perception and action resources contextually. Part I introduced the free-energy principle (FEP) and active inference as Bayesian prediction-error minimization, explaining the control problem in active inference systems and reviewing classical and quantum FEP formulations. Part II demonstrates that active inference systems driven by the FEP can represent their control flow systems as tensor networks (TNs). It shows how TNs as control systems can be implemented within quantum topological neural networks and discusses implications for modeling biological systems at multiple scales.
chunks.topic: Control flow in active inference systems
chunks.chunk_summary: Active inference systems driven by the FEP can represent their control flow as tensor networks, which can be implemented within quantum topological neural networks to model biological systems.

chunks.text: Active inference provides a scale-free framework for describing system interactions in cognitive terms. Part I reviewed how active inference, combining learning and active exploration, emerges in FEP-compliant systems. The control flow problem arises in these systems, involving switching between classical dynamical attractors, deployed quantum reference frames (QRFs), and computational processes represented by TQFTs. Control flow has a free-energy cost, requiring a trade-off between processing costs and switching benefits. Time and memory dependence of control flow leads to context effects on perception and action.
chunks.chunk_summary: Active inference systems face a control flow problem involving switching between different modes, with associated free-energy costs and context effects.

chunks.text: Part II develops a general tensor representation of control flow and proves its factorization into a TN if separability conditions for identifying environmental features are met. TN architectures enable control flow classification, with examples provided. Relationships between TNs and artificial neural networks (ANNs) are discussed, generalizing to topological quantum neural networks, of which standard deep-learning architectures are a classical limit. Implications for biology are explored, correlating TN architecture with system observational capabilities, particularly spatial locality and mereology. Known control pathways are classified by TN architecture, and the TN representation's use in experimental design is considered.
chunks.topic: Tensor network representation and biological implications
chunks.chunk_summary: Control flow can be represented by tensor networks, which can be classified and related to ANNs and TQNNs, with implications for biological control systems and experimental design.

chunks.text: Entanglement and quantum error correction are fundamental to understanding quantum gravity. Black holes have entropy proportional to their horizon area, implying maximal entropy and a holographic conjecture. AdS/CFT postulates duality between gravity in AdS space and quantum field theory at its spatial infinity. The Ryu-Takayanagi (RT) formula proposes that boundary region entanglement follows the black hole entropy law, linking spacetime structure and quantum entanglement. Quantum gravity must be holographic, with states satisfying the RT formula.
chunks.section: Tensor Network Representation of Control Flow
chunks.chunk_summary: The holographic principle, supported by the RT formula, connects spacetime structure and quantum entanglement, suggesting that quantum gravity must be holographic.

chunks.text: The correspondence between bulk gravity and boundary quantum theory raises locality issues. Bulk variables can be controlled instantaneously from the boundary, requiring access to a large boundary portion. Local boundary observers still experience locality and a speed of light limit, similar to quantum error correction codes (QECCs). Bulk locality is a QECC property of the encoding map realizing the duality. These properties are connected to RT, which provides entanglement for QECC emergence. The RT formula and QECC are fulfilled by tensor networks, which are efficient representations of quantum many-body systems.
chunks.section: Tensor Network Representation of Control Flow
chunks.chunk_summary: Locality in the bulk emerges as a property of quantum error correction, linked to the RT formula and entanglement provided by tensor networks.

chunks.text: A system exhibits non-trivial control flow if and only if it can be represented by a TN. Trivial control flow means deploying only one QRF or mutually-commuting QRFs. Systems with trivial control flow "do the same thing" regardless of context. No finite system can measure its entire boundary state with a single QRF, so no system can simultaneously measure and act on its entire context. Systems deploying multiple QRFs experience contextuality due to unobservable effects. Every action by an "interesting" system increases VFE at its boundary.
chunks.section: Tensor Network Representation of Control Flow
chunks.chunk_summary: Non-trivial control flow, characterized by the deployment of multiple, non-commuting QRFs, can be represented by a tensor network.
chunks.authors: ["Chris Fields", "Filippo Fabbrocini", "Karl Friston", "James F. Glazebrook", "Hava Siegelmann", "Michael Levin", "Antonio Marciano"]
chunks.journal: IEEE Transactions on Molecular, Biological, and Multi-Scale Communications

chunks.text: Classical control flow in a system deploying multiple QRFs can be represented by a matrix of transition probabilities. Each transition has an energetic cost paid by free energy. This matrix is a 2-tensor decomposable into a TN. Any non-trivial control flow can be written as a linear sequence of operators, encodable by spatial indices for contraction. Thus, any non-trivial control flow can be written as a flat TN, repeatable at larger scales to create a hierarchical TN. Decoherent reference sectors exist if and only if control flow is implemented by a TN. Decoherence requires independently deployable, non-commuting QRFs, necessitating a factorable control structure, hence a TN. Conversely, a TN factors the control structure, enabling independent QRF deployment and decoherence.
chunks.section: Tensor Network Representation of Control Flow
chunks.chunk_summary: Control flow can be represented by a tensor network, which enables decoherence through independent deployment of non-commuting QRFs.

chunks.text: The TN of any FEP-compliant system is a decomposition of the Identity. The FEP drives systems to return to their NESS after perturbations. At a large scale, the TN of such a system is a cycle, decomposing the Identity. Many TN models assume asymptotic boundary conditions, yielding a cyclic system. Theorem 1 and its corollaries classify systems by control architectures. Hierarchical depth indicates virtual machine layers, with interfaces implementing coarse-graining. Number and location of contractions yielding unitary operators build entanglement between lower-level operators. A MERA entangles every pair of lower-level operators at every level.
chunks.section: Tensor Network Representation of Control Flow
chunks.chunk_summary: The tensor network of an FEP-compliant system decomposes the Identity, reflecting the system's tendency to return to its NESS, and can be classified by hierarchical depth and entanglement structure.

chunks.text: Control-flow architecture specifies the layout of distinguishable sectors on the boundary and detectable features/objects. Locality requires a hierarchical TN, while detectable entanglement requires a MERA-like TN. Locality is necessary for features/objects to have nested components. QRFs for spacetime must be hierarchical, and MERAs if space entanglement is detectable. A MERA is required to detect coherence between spatially-separated systems as a computational resource.
chunks.section: Tensor Network Representation of Control Flow
chunks.chunk_summary: The control-flow architecture, represented by a tensor network, determines the detectable features and objects, with hierarchical TNs for locality and MERA-like TNs for entanglement.

chunks.text: Tensor networks can be associated with matrix elements of physical scalar products among topological quantum neural networks (TQNNs). These scalar products encode TQFT dynamics, fulfilling flatness and gauge invariance constraints. Matrix elements act as evolution matrix elements for spin-network states spanning TQNN Hilbert spaces. BF theories, a class of TQFTs, are used in particle physics, gravity, condensed matter, quantum information, quantum computation, machine learning, and neuroscience. They are defined on a principal bundle with a connection for a gauge group, with an action involving a trace over internal indices ensuring gauge invariance.
chunks.chunk_summary: Tensor networks represent the evolution of TQNN states, with BF theories providing a framework for various applications including machine learning and neuroscience.

chunks.text: Variation of the BF theory action with respect to the connection and frame-field yields the equations of motion: curvature constraint (flat connection) and Gauß constraint (gauge invariance). Quantum states of the kinematical Hilbert space are represented by cylindrical functionals supported on graphs with holonomies and intertwiner operators. For SU(2), spin-networks form a basis of the kinematical Hilbert space. The spin-network cylindrical functional can be decomposed using the Peter-Weyl transform and Wigner matrices. Functorial evolution among spin-networks is ensured by a projector operator implementing the curvature constraint in the physical scalar product.
chunks.chunk_summary: The quantum states of BF theories are represented by spin-networks, with evolution governed by a projector operator implementing the curvature constraint.

chunks.text: Matrix elements of the physical scalar product give rise to an n-tensor. Considering stochastic noise and out-of-equilibrium dynamics involves heat-flow evolution of fields. Langevin equations with stochastic noise describe relaxation towards equilibrium. Out-of-equilibrium dynamics is characterized by broken symmetries of the equations of motion. Geometric heat-flow, like Ricci flow, involves the gravitational field and Einstein equations. Stochastic Ricci flow (SRF) with multiplicative noise has been analyzed in ADM variables. Equilibration trajectories correspond to renormalization group (RG) flow, with thermal time as the scale parameter. For BF theories, geometric RG flow is the TQFT equivalent of gravitational Ricci flow.
chunks.chunk_summary: Out-of-equilibrium dynamics in TQFTs, described by Langevin equations and stochastic Ricci flow, can be understood as a renormalization group flow, with thermal time as the scale parameter.

chunks.text: Tensor networks are used in machine learning for representing and manipulating high-dimensional data, such as in image and video classification. They can also process data using various operators, making them effective for machine learning applications.  TNs are well-suited for representing quantum many-body states. The machine learning approach involves lifting data to higher spaces, applying a linear classifier to a non-linear space, and compressing weights using TNs. The output separates classes that are not linearly separable in a linear space. The decision function is the overlap of the weight tensor with the feature map tensor. The weight tensor can be approximated by decomposition. Regularization and optimization are built as a constructive product of low-order tensors, while weight compression uses Matrix Product States (MPS) decomposition.
chunks.chunk_summary: Tensor networks are used in machine learning for representing, manipulating, and processing high-dimensional data, enabling non-linear classification and weight compression.

chunks.text: The TN framework generalizes main machine learning model architectures like Support Vector Machines, Kernel models, and Deep Neural Networks. Deep Neural Networks can be seen as a piecewise composition of linear discriminators.  The literature on tensor theory in traditional ML is growing.  Stoudenmire and Schwab adapted TN optimization algorithms to supervised learning using MPS. Novikov, Trofimov, and Oseledets showed how an exponentially large parameter tensor can be represented in a factorized Tensor Train (TT) format for model regularization. Van Glasser, Pancotti, and Cirac connected TNs and probabilistic graphical models.  Other work used MPS for generative models and unsupervised learning, achieving performance comparable to standard models.  Finally, the contribution of polynomials of different degrees to supervised learning performance has been analyzed.
chunks.topic: Tensor networks and machine learning architectures
chunks.chunk_summary: Tensor networks generalize various machine learning architectures, and their application in supervised and unsupervised learning is an active area of research.

chunks.text: Scale-free biology requires a smooth transition from quantum-like to classical-like behavior.  Metabolic, signal-transduction, and gene-regulatory pathways are typically represented classically, despite involving quantum mechanisms. Free-energy considerations suggest that cells use quantum coherence computationally. Evidence for large-scale entanglement in mammalian brains suggests quantum coherence as a resource. Control flow models must support quantum computation, which hierarchical TNs with unitary components, like MERAs, provide. Prokaryotes primarily adapt metabolism and initiate replication, suggesting shallow control hierarchies. Eukaryotes have intracellular compartmentalization and morphological degrees of freedom, leading to deep control hierarchies at the cellular level, correlating with morphological structure in complex cells and multicellular assemblages. This correlates with increased computational power in eukaryotes compared to prokaryotes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Scale-free biology necessitates a transition from quantum to classical behavior, with control flow models supporting quantum computation using hierarchical TNs, and eukaryotes exhibiting deeper control hierarchies than prokaryotes.

chunks.text: Eukaryotes implement active exploration, communication, and stigmergic memory, requiring QRFs for spacetime and specific objects. These QRFs rely on symmetries and error-correcting codes. Spacetime as a QECC implemented by TNs has been studied extensively. Organisms use spacetime as an error-correcting code, but neural implementation details are unclear. Context sensitivity and context effects due to non-commutativity increase with network complexity and depth. Bowtie networks with high fan-in/fan-out are ubiquitous in higher eukaryotes, introducing semantic ambiguities resolved by context. Each signal has its own semantics, but context can depend on unpredictable boundary conditions. Context change is problematic if joint probability distributions are undefined, occurring when QRFs don't commute. This affects deep learning using VAEs. The structure of Diagram 3 in Part I can benchmark signal transduction networks for co-deployable versus non-co-deployable QRFs.
chunks.chunk_summary: Eukaryotic control networks exhibit context sensitivity and context effects due to non-commutativity, with bowtie networks introducing semantic ambiguities resolved by context, and the structure of Diagram 3 in Part I serving as a benchmark.

chunks.text: \"Quantum\" context effects due to non-commutativity have been reported even in human language use. The \"Snow Queen\" experiment challenged subjects with inconsistent meanings of terms in different contexts, detecting statistically-significant context effects using the CbD formalism. These effects cannot be explained by linguistic ambiguity. Language-driven contextuality is studied in psycholinguistics and distributional semantics, combining CbD and sheaf theoretic methods to analyze semantic ambiguity. While \"languages\" applied to cells and tissues is metaphorical, linguistic approaches may be useful for understanding context dependence and ambiguity in biology. Immune cell responses can be dysfunctional due to context changes, seen as discrepancies between signal semantics and the immune system's \"language.\" Similar context effects observed in microbiological systems, like lactose-glucose interference in E. Coli, require non-classical probabilities. The term \"quantum-like\" is often used, but the formal structure is quantum theory.
chunks.chunk_summary: Context effects due to non-commutativity appear in language and biological systems, suggesting that linguistic approaches may be useful for understanding context dependence and semantic ambiguity in biology, including immune responses and microbiological systems.

chunks.text: Further research in quantum biology may offer insights into human physiology and cognition. Allostasis regulates physiological conditions relative to costs and benefits, dynamically allocating resources for adaptability. Visceromotor cortical regions generate autonomic, hormonal, and immunological predictions for interoceptive inference. This inference putatively utilizes predictive coding for homeostasis-allostasis through a hierarchy of systems, connecting interoception to extercoception and proprioception. Allostasis protects against surprise by minimizing free energy of internal states. The Good Regulator theorem shows that regulation requires an internal model. An integrated allostatic-interoceptive cortical system supports psychological phenomena like memory and emotions. Cognitive conditions like depression and autism have been described as abnormalities of allostatic-interoceptive inference, impairing predictive coding due to aberrant assimilation of prediction errors.
chunks.chunk_summary: Allostasis and interoceptive inference, utilizing predictive coding and hierarchical systems, play a crucial role in regulating physiological conditions and protecting against surprise, with abnormalities potentially leading to cognitive conditions.

chunks.text: This context-sensitive control flow model is important for understanding morphogenesis, a context-sensitive error-minimizing process. The collective intelligence of cells during development, regeneration, and metamorphosis creates and repairs complex structures despite perturbations.  The ability of cells to reach the correct target morphology despite interventions requires understanding how they navigate problem spaces, including anatomical, physiological, and transcriptional spaces. Understanding navigation policies of unconventional collective intelligences can help understand creative problem-solving and predict synthetic being behavior.
chunks.chunk_summary: Morphogenesis is a context-sensitive process driven by the collective intelligence of cells, and understanding their navigation policies in various problem spaces is crucial for understanding development, regeneration, and predicting synthetic being behavior.

chunks.text: This work shows how the control flow problem arises in active inference systems and provides three formal representations. Control flow in such systems can always be represented by a tensor network. The general formalism of topological quantum neural networks implements a general model of control flow. These results characterize context dependence in active inference systems at any scale. The concept of communication by language is not metaphorical for biological systems but an appropriate description of interactional dynamics. These results are a step toward integrating physics, biology, and cognitive science, allowing classification of systems by organizational and computational complexity and understanding how simpler system interactions implement complex behavior in larger systems.
chunks.topic: Integrating physics, biology, and cognitive science
chunks.chunk_summary: This work provides a framework for understanding control flow in active inference systems using tensor networks and topological quantum neural networks, characterizing context dependence and suggesting that communication by language is an appropriate description for biological systems.

chunks.text: Chris Fields is an information theorist working in AI, neuromorphic computing, and bioinformatics, focusing on the interface between quantum information, computing, and life sciences. Filippo Fabrocini is a Professor at Tongji University, Director of the Tongji Sustainable AI Lab, and a founder of the Tongji AI Art Lab, also affiliated with the Italy National Research Council. His interests include Machine Learning, Quantum Neural Networks, Ethical AI, and AI Art. Karl Friston is a theoretical neuroscientist and expert on brain imaging, inventor of statistical parametric mapping, voxel-based morphometry, and dynamic causal modelling, architect of the free energy principle and active inference, Fellow of the Royal Society, and recipient of the Weldon Memorial Prize. James F. Glazebrook is Professor Emeritus at Eastern Illinois University and Adjunct Faculty at the University of Illinois, researching mathematical methods in cognitive science, scale-free architectures, and information theory applied to contextuality and active inference. Hananel Hazan is a research scientist at the Allen Discovery Center at Tufts University, focusing on biologically-inspired computing and neurocomputation, exploring computational properties of neuronal and non-neuronal systems. Michael Levin is Distinguished Professor and Vannevar Bush Chair at Tufts University, director of the Allen Discovery Center, and Associate Faculty at the Wyss Institute, working on developmental biology, computer science, and behavioral science to understand cognition in complex systems. Antonino Marcianò is a professor of physics at Fudan University and member of the Italian Institute of Nuclear Physics, focusing on theoretical physics, quantum field theories, gravity, and applications to solid state physics, AI, and quantum computation.
